summary.title: Database Systems
summary.description: This course covers methods for designing relational databases, the use of SQL to define and access a database, and the use of a production-level database management system to implement a relational database system. The student is required to complete a project in which they either implement a real-world example relational database, or (at the instructor's discretion and approval) research a specific database topic not covered during the class. Additional topics that may be discussed as time and class interest permit include: integrating databases into applications or web sites; alternative database paradigms; database design/engineering tools; and underlying implementation of databases.

course-outcomes.outcome: Demonstrate use of the SQL language to define and access relational data.
Demonstrate at least one database modeling technique (e.g., entity-relationship model).
Implement a real-world relational database of significant complexity.
Develop a database from a given set of specifications.
Understand database administration, performance, and Big Data.

laboratory-studio-outcomes.summary: The laboratory provides an opportunity for students to become competent with a variety of modern database tools. The development and presentation of a large project is the capstone experience for this course.

outline.room-requirements: Computer lab needed for the lab component
